Description: Few things are as reliable as fitting a sizeable rock on a stick.
An ornate sword carved from wood.
Evidence suggests that the earliest tomahawks were tied together with animal sinew.
Prior to Colombian Exchange, tomahawks used by the natives were made from both stone and bone.
After the arrival of European, tomahawks began to be tipped with iron and steel.
A descendent of the medieval falchion, the cutlass is synonymous with the Age of Exploration.
By the Industrial Age, the musket had cemented itself as the choice weapon of war.
Over a million M14 rifles were produced in the 60s and 70s.
Native American made war shields and medicine shields - the latter to protect the spirit of the warrior.
Plains Indians considered their shield as their most precious possession.
Natives used bowls for ritual and everyday purposes.
Clay for pottery often had to be mined and purified in labor-intensive processes.
Ever-increasingly sophisticated designs on pottery can be found in discoveries from almost every part of the world.
European settlers arriving in the new world often brought their own designs and production methods for their vessels.
Hardened leather was a common component in Native American armor.
The cuirass had become the most common form of body armor by the Age of Exploration.
By the time of the American Civil War, soldiers' uniforms had begun to be mass produced.

ArtifactName: Ancient Native American Wampum Bead Currency
Description: Wampum beads were not only used for trade, but also for clothing and decorative purposes.
Atleast some groups from almost every continent have been recorded as using shells for currency.

ArtifactName: Medieval Native American Wampum Bead Currency
Description: It was not until the arrival or Europeans that wampum beads took on a primarily commercial function.
